Outline - Film 6: "Examples from the Secondary School
Page 2
III. STATEMENT OF FILM'S BASIC CONCEPTS
A. Confronting the student with the television receiver and its message, however
colorful, is not synonymous with moving that message those last difficult,
vital inches.
B. The good high school teacher, knowing this, will see it as his job to integrate
television lessons into the previous learnings and the ongoing experience of
pupils in order to insure maximum learning.
C. The television segments of any unit of study must be.. .or be made to be...
an integral part of that unit.
IV. PREPARATION OF VIEWER FOR ILLUSTRATIONS TO COME (Narrator explains
that we will see representative classroom activities used by high school teachers to
integrate certain lessons into particular units of study. The utilization of one lesson
will be explored in some depth. Narrator calls attention to sometimes-interchangeable
nature of preparation and follow-up activities.)
V. BRIEF ILLUSTRATIONS (Television lesson stipulated in detail but not shown)
A. AMERICAN PROBLEMS Class (12th Grade) (Social Studies)
Subject: The Two-Party System
Television lesson: "Practical Politics"
PREPARATION: The book and television program—The Making of a President—
are reviewed by teacher and students who read or saw. Teacher
explains that one such case study will be in the television lesson
Students are to view with the idea of estimating how typical and
representative are the "ward heelers" in the television case.
OR
FOLLOW-THROUGH: Discussion of financial, moral, personal problems faced
by candidates for public office. Discussion climaxed
by students volunteering to interview local politicians
on the problem.
B. HEALTH EDUCATION class (11th Grade)
Subject: Smoking and Lung Cancer
Television lesson: Aulhority (Public health officer or physician) showed lab
specimans of diseased lungs.. .young and old...
and discussed problem.
